org.strongback.control

Interface TalonController

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Controller, LimitedMotor, Motor, PIDController, Requirable, SpeedController, SpeedSensor, Stoppable, TalonSRX

    @Experimental
public interface TalonController
extends PIDController, TalonSRX
    A hardware-based Proportional Integral Differential (PID) controller that runs on the Talon SRX motor controller. The controller's input is wired as a sensor on the Talon SRX device, and specified via the TalonSRX.setFeedbackDevice(FeedbackDevice) method. The controller's mode of control is set via the setControlMode(ControlMode).

    Important usage notes

    This section outlines some useful and frequently used features of the TalonController.

    Ramp rate

    The Talon SRX can be set to honor a ramp rate to prevent instantaneous changes in throttle. This ramp rate is in effect regardless of which mode is selected (throttle, slave, or closed-loop). 

     controller.setVoltageRampRate(6.0); // Allow throttle changes up to 6.0V per second

    Feedback device

    The analog and quadrature signals are available all the time in all modes (throttle, slave, or closed-loop), but the Talon SRX requires the robot application to "pick" a particular feedback device for soft limit and closed-loop features. The Talon SRX defaults to the quadrature encoder. 

     controller.setFeedbackDevice(FeedbackDevice.ANALOG_ENCODER);

    In order for limit switches and closed-loop features to function correctly, the sensor and motor have to be “in-phase”. This means that the sensor position must move in a positive direction as the motor controller drives positive throttle. To test this, first drive the motor manually (using a human input device), and watch the sensor position either in the roboRIO Web-based Configuration Self-Test, or by calling TalonSRX.getSelectedSensor() and printing it to console. If the "Sensor Position" moves in a negative direction while Talon SRX throttle is positive (blinking green), then use the reverseSensor(boolean) so that the Talon negates the sensor reading. Then re-test to confirm sensed position moves in a positive direction with positive motor drive.

    In the special case of using the TalonSRX.FeedbackDevice.ENCODER_RISING feedback device, reverseSensor(boolean) should be called with false, since a rising encoder is guaranteed to be positive since it increments per rising edge, and never decrements.

    Soft limits

    Soft limits can be used to disable motor drive when the position value read from the feedback device is outside of a specified range. Forward throttle will be disabled when enableForwardSoftLimit(boolean) is set to true and the sensor position is greater than the setForwardSoftLimit(int) value. Reverse throttle will be disabled when enableReverseSoftLimit(boolean) is set to true and the sensor position is less than the setReverseSoftLimit(int).

    Control modes

    The closed-loop logic is the same regardless of which feedback sensor or closed-loop mode is selected.

    Follower mode

    Any Talon SRX on CAN bus can be instructed to "follow" the drive output of another Talon SRX. This is done by putting a Talon SRX into "follower" mode and specifying the device ID of the "lead Talon". The follower Talon will then mirror the output of the leader, which can be in any mode: closed-loop, voltage percent (duty-cycle), or even following yet another Talon SRX. 

     leaderController = ...
 followerController.setControlMode(ControlMode.FOLLOWER);
 followerController.withTarget(leaderController.getDeviceID());
    The reverseOutput(boolean) method can be used to invert the output of a follower Talon. This may be useful if a follower and leader Talon are wired out of phase with each other.

    This class is currently experimental. It certainly works as a simple motor, but most of this interface exposes functionality of the Talon SRX motor controller, including various input sensors. Little beyond setting and reading the speed has been tested.

      • reverseSensor

        TalonController reverseSensor(boolean flip)
        Description copied from interface: TalonSRX
        Flips the sign (multiplies by negative one) the feedback device values read by the Talon.

        This only affects position and velocity closed loop control. Allows for situations where you may have a sensor flipped and going in the wrong direction.

        Specified by:
        reverseSensor in interface TalonSRX
        Parameters:
        flip - true if sensor input should be flipped, or false if not.
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null

      • setForwardSoftLimit

        TalonController setForwardSoftLimit(int forwardLimitInDegrees)
        Description copied from interface: TalonSRX
        Set the soft limit for the forward throttle, in terms of the angle as measured by the selected input sensor. Soft limits can be used to disable motor drive when the "Sensor Position" is outside of a specified range: forward throttle will be disabled if the "Sensor Position" is greater than the forward soft limit. This takes effect only when the forward soft limit is TalonSRX.enableForwardSoftLimit(boolean).

        Soft limits can be used to disable motor drive when the “Sensor Position” is outside of a specified range. Forward throttle will be disabled if the “Sensor Position” is greater than the Forward Soft Limit. Reverse throttle will be disabled if the “Sensor Position” is less than the Reverse Soft Limit. The respective Soft Limit Enable must be enabled for this feature to take effect.

        Specified by:
        setForwardSoftLimit in interface TalonSRX
        Parameters:
        forwardLimitInDegrees - the angle at which the forward throttle should be disabled, where the angle in terms of the TalonSRX.getSelectedSensor()
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        See Also:
        TalonSRX.enableForwardSoftLimit(boolean)

      • setReverseSoftLimit

        TalonController setReverseSoftLimit(int reverseLimitInDegrees)
        Description copied from interface: TalonSRX
        Set the soft limit for the reverse throttle, in terms of the angle as measured by the selected input sensor. Soft limits can be used to disable motor drive when the "Sensor Position" it outside of a specified range: reverse throttle will be disabled if the "Sensor Position" is less than the reverse soft limit. This takes effect only when the reverse soft limit is TalonSRX.enableReverseSoftLimit(boolean).

        Soft limits can be used to disable motor drive when the “Sensor Position” is outside of a specified range. Forward throttle will be disabled if the “Sensor Position” is greater than the Forward Soft Limit. Reverse throttle will be disabled if the “Sensor Position” is less than the Reverse Soft Limit. The respective Soft Limit Enable must be enabled for this feature to take effect.

        Specified by:
        setReverseSoftLimit in interface TalonSRX
        Parameters:
        reverseLimitInDegrees - the angle at which the reverse throttle should be disabled, where the angle in terms of the TalonSRX.getSelectedSensor()
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        See Also:

      • withGains

        TalonController withGains(double p,
                          double i,
                          double d,
                          double feedForward,
                          int izone,
                          double closeLoopRampRate)
        Set the gains for the current profile of this controller.
        Parameters:
        p - the proportional gain
        i - the integral gain
        d - the differential gain
        feedForward - the feed-forward gain
        izone - Integration zone -- prevents accumulation of integration error with large errors. Setting this to zero will ignore any izone stuff.
        closeLoopRampRate - Closed loop ramp rate. Maximum change in voltage, in volts / sec.
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        See Also:
        PIDController.useProfile(int)

      • withProfile

        TalonController withProfile(int profile,
                            double p,
                            double i,
                            double d)
        Description copied from interface: PIDController
        Set the control gains for the specified profile, which may or may not be the current profile. Profile numbers start from 0 and can include any integers, although consecutive non-zero numbers are encouraged. The default profile is 0.
        Specified by:
        withProfile in interface PIDController
        Parameters:
        profile - the profile number; a new profile will be created if a profile with the number does not exist may be an existing or new profile
        p - the proportional gain
        i - the integral gain
        d - the differential gain
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null

      • withProfile

        TalonController withProfile(int profile,
                            double p,
                            double i,
                            double d,
                            double feedForward,
                            int izone,
                            double closeLoopRampRate)
        Set the gains for the specified profile of this controller.
        Parameters:
        profile - which profile to set the PID constants for. You can have two profiles, with values of 0 or 1, allowing you to keep a second set of values on hand in the Talon. In order to switch profiles without recalling setPID, you must call setProfile().
        p - the proportional gain
        i - the integral gain
        d - the differential gain
        feedForward - the feed-forward gain
        izone - Integration zone -- prevents accumulation of integration error with large errors. Setting this to zero will ignore any izone stuff.
        closeLoopRampRate - Closed loop ramp rate. Maximum change in voltage, in volts / sec.
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        See Also:
        PIDController.useProfile(int)

      • setVoltageRampRate

        TalonController setVoltageRampRate(double rampRate)
        Description copied from interface: TalonSRX
        The Talon SRX can be set to honor a ramp rate to prevent instantaneous changes in throttle. This ramp rate is in effect regardless of which mode is selected (throttle, slave, or closed-loop). For example, setting the ramp rate to 6.0 will limit the maximum voltage change within any second to be less than or equal to 6.0 volts.
        Specified by:
        setVoltageRampRate in interface TalonSRX
        Parameters:
        rampRate - maximum change in voltage per second, in volts / second
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null

      • setExpiration

        TalonController setExpiration(double timeout)
        Description copied from interface: TalonSRX
        Set the motor safety expiration time in milliseconds. When safety is enabled, then the motor will be automatically disabled if it is not used within the expiration time, which is typically 100ms. This can be adjusted to a larger value when debugging the robot.
        Specified by:
        setExpiration in interface TalonSRX
        Parameters:
        timeout - the safety expiration time in milliseconds
        Returns:
        this instance so that methods can be chained; never null
